articles.title: Plans to limit jury trials in England and Wales may be watered down after backlash
articles.trailText: Exclusive: David Lammy’s proposals could be altered to avoid fight in Lords after criticism from MPs, peers and lawyers
articles.summary: Justice secretary David Lammy’s reforms would bar jury trials for offences carrying sentences up to three years, introduce judge-only “swift courts” and boost magistrates’ sentencing powers from 12 to 18 months to halve jury trials and clear an 80,000-case backlog. Fierce opposition from MPs, peers and senior lawyers has prompted officials to consider reverting to Brian Leveson’s model—two lay magistrates alongside judges and a two-year threshold—to avoid a bruising Lords battle. Ministers are confident of Commons approval but wary of another high-profile U-turn.

articles.title: UK right to weigh diplomacy before ‘calling out’ allies on international law breaches, says attorney general
articles.trailText: Exclusive: In first comments since US attack on Venezuela, Richard Hermer refrains from singling out Trump administration
articles.summary: AG Richard Hermer said in a Guardian interview that states have the right to consider diplomatic relations — using statecraft — before publicly condemning allies’ alleged breaches of international law. In his first comments since Britain’s muted response to the US attack on Venezuela, he refrained from naming the Trump administration and argued that upholding the rules-based order serves UK interests. He warned against flouting rules, defended Labour’s domestic rights record versus Reform UK’s agenda, championed the ECHR and mounted a robust defence of Keir Starmer’s leadership.

articles.title: Labour must raise the age of criminal responsibility | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Prof Roger Evans supports Lady Hale’s view that prosecuting children under 14 is wrong
articles.summary: Prof Roger Evans urges Labour to raise the age of criminal responsibility from 10 to at least 14, aligning with most European countries and Lady Hale’s recommendation. He rejects the Ministry of Justice’s early-intervention justification, citing research on high recidivism and contrasting Norway’s welfare-led response to six-year-old killers in the Silje Redergård case—full rehabilitation and privacy—with the punitive fallout of the James Bulger case. Evans warns it would be Labour’s lasting shame not to adopt this evidence-based reform.

articles.title: Top judges join call for England and Wales to raise age of criminal responsibility to 14
articles.trailText: Children can be investigated by police, charged with a crime and put on trial from age 10, the joint lowest age in Europe
articles.summary: Former Supreme Court president Lady Hale and Lady Butler-Sloss co-sponsored an amendment to the Crime and Policing Bill seeking to raise England and Wales’s age of criminal responsibility from 10 to 14. Charities, neuroscience experts and the UN argue pre-14 brains are underdeveloped, undermining children’s ability to engage with proceedings; ministers oppose. England and Wales currently share Europe’s lowest threshold (with Switzerland), allowing police investigation, charges and trials for 10-year-olds. In 2023–24 about 3,400 children aged 10–14 were cautioned or sentenced. Critics call such prosecutions “barbaric” and out of step with civilised norms; the government cites early intervention and youth court diversion.

articles.title: Sarah Burton obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Legal and environmental activist who held senior roles at Greenpeace UK, Greenpeace International and Amnesty International
articles.summary: Sarah Burton, who died aged 73 from appendix cancer, was a US-born solicitor and pioneering legal counsel for Greenpeace UK and Amnesty International. After qualifying in 1980, she secured a high court jury order in the Blair Peach inquest and defended striking miners. As Greenpeace UK’s first in-house lawyer (1990–2002), she advised on direct action against BNFL’s sea dumping. She joined Amnesty in 2006 as campaign programme director and managed Greenpeace International programmes (2009–18), notably defending Sumatran communities. Founder of Lawyers for Nuclear Disarmament and board member of Natural England and Public Law Project, she mentored women activists. Survived by her partner, daughter Hannah, and brother.

articles.title: Labour MPs revolt over ‘madness’ of jury-scrapping plans
articles.trailText: Letter from 39 backbenchers threatens rebellion over proposal to expedite court backlog in England and Wales
articles.summary: Thirty-nine Labour backbenchers have signed a letter warning that plans to remove thousands of jury trials in England and Wales — proposed by Justice Secretary David Lammy and Sir Brian Leveson to tackle a crown court backlog of nearly 80,000 cases — constitute “madness” and an undue erosion of a fundamental right. Lead coordinator Karl Turner, who says the reforms are unworkable and that private contractors (Serco) are also to blame for delays, threatened to break the party whip. Downing Street insists sweeping change is essential, with PM Starmer affirming juries will remain cornerstone for the most serious cases.

articles.title: What the media get wrong on the ECHR and ‘the right to family life’ | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Retired immigration judge Jane Coker points out that it’s the right to respect for family life that the European convention on human rights protects
articles.summary: Retired immigration judge Jane Coker criticises media misphrasing Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights as a “right to family life,” clarifying it protects only “respect for family life.” Coker cites the Bonavero report: deportation can be halted only if removal causes “unduly harsh” impact and public interest is outweighed. Just 0.73% of foreign national offenders succeed in human rights appeals. Parenthood or partnership in the UK does not guarantee reprieve. She highlights the Home Office’s lack of transparency on removals and urges evidence-based enforcement over blaming judges or the law for systemic failures.

articles.title: International law on the killing of people who survive an attack at sea | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: William Schabas on the conviction of two officers of a German submarine of ‘an offence against the law of nations’ during the first world war
articles.summary: Professor William Schabas recalls a 1919 German court trial under the Treaty of Versailles that convicted two U-86 submarine officers of an ‘offence against the law of nations’ for murdering survivors of the Canadian hospital ship Llandovery Castle off Ireland in late WWI. The judges ruled the ban on attacking shipwrecked seamen simple and universally known, dismissing superior-orders as manifestly unlawful. This precedent informed a 1945 war-crimes judgment and is enshrined in the ICC’s Rome Statute.

articles.title: Business groups urge Tory peers to stop blocking Labour’s workers’ rights bill
articles.trailText: Six of Britain’s biggest employer groups fear compromise deal brokered with bosses and union leaders is at risk
articles.summary: Six top employer groups (CBI, BCC, CIPD, FSB, REC, Small Business Britain) urged Tory Lords to stop blocking Labour’s workers’ rights bill before Christmas, warning delays could scuttle a compromise reducing unfair dismissal qualifying period to six months. Peers have repeatedly voted to remove the compensation cap, prompting CityUK warnings of unlimited high-earner payouts that deter investment. Business Secretary Peter Kyle pledged secondary legislation consultations post-passage. Commons approval is expected Monday, with a final Lords stage Tuesday.

articles.title: ‘Who’s it going to be next time?’: ECHR rethink is ‘moral retreat’, say rights experts
articles.trailText: As 27 European countries urge changes to laws forged after second world war, human rights chief says politicians are playing into hands of populists
articles.summary: Twenty-seven European states, led by Denmark, Italy and Poland, have urged revision of the post-WWII European Convention on Human Rights, arguing current rules hinder migration control and sovereignty. Human rights experts, including Council of Europe commissioner Michael O'Flaherty, denounce the move as a moral retreat fueled by populist rhetoric linking migration and crime, warn of a hierarchised system undermining universal protections, and cite University of Oxford research showing UK media misreports on ECHR cases. They reject modernisation, saying it offers false hope and endangers the convention's founding principles.

articles.title: Sickened by Keir Starmer’s call to curb human rights | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Nick Moss, Dr Deborah Talbot, Dimitra Blana and Mary Pimm on the prime minister’s plan to ‘protect our borders’ and Donald Trump’s accusations that Europe is ‘weak’ and ‘decaying’
articles.summary: Four letters condemn PM Keir Starmer’s call to amend the European Convention on Human Rights to ‘control our borders’, calling it a betrayal by a former human rights lawyer and proof of social democracy’s ideological bankruptcy. Contributors argue that curbing the ECHR echoes Donald Trump’s anti-immigration rhetoric, scapegoats refugees, and dismisses migrants’ cultural and economic contributions. They insist Europe needs policies on housing, wages, inequality and public services, not hard-border politics, and warn that chasing the far right’s illiberal agenda is self-defeating.

articles.title: Brittany Higgins declared bankrupt after Linda Reynolds wins defamation case
articles.trailText: Former defence minister’s application to have former staffer bankrupted has been approved in a Western Australian court
articles.summary: Brittany Higgins was bankrupted by a Federal Court order on 12 Dec, following ex-senator Linda Reynolds’ successful defamation case. Reynolds, awarded $315,000 plus $26,109 interest and 80% of costs (over $1m), sued over defamatory social media posts and is now probing how Higgins spent her $2.4m compensation. A court-appointed trustee will seize assets, sell property or garnish earnings to satisfy creditors and trace any remaining settlement funds. Bankruptcy typically lasts three years, affecting credit access and travel without trustee approval.

articles.title: Britain threatened to cut off ICC funding over Netanyahu arrest warrant, claims prosecutor
articles.trailText: Karim Khan makes allegation in court submission while defending decision to prosecute Israeli prime minister in 2024
articles.summary: ICC prosecutor Karim Khan alleges that in April 2024 a senior British official—reportedly then-foreign secretary David Cameron—threatened to withdraw UK funding and prompt Britain’s exit from the Rome statute if the court pressed ahead with arrest warrants for Benjamin Netanyahu and Yoav Gallant. He also claims US officials warned of disastrous fallout and US senator Lindsey Graham cautioned Hamas might kill hostages if warrants were issued. Khan says he pressed on, citing no Israeli cooperation, and defends his neutrality amid unrelated sexual misconduct allegations that surfaced in May and were later revived online. He highlights his meticulous, expert-led preparation and a 22-page response to Israel’s challenge to the warrants.

articles.title: Roger Warren Evans obituary
articles.trailText: Barrister and social entrepreneur whose remarkable career ranged from immigration adviser to TV presenter and Labour councillor
articles.summary: Roger Warren Evans (1935–2025), barrister and social entrepreneur, co-invented community interest companies after a 2000s wine-bar discussion, enshrined in the 2004 Companies Act, now counting 37,000 UK CICs. Educated at Leighton Park and Cambridge, with Royal Navy service, he won landmark human rights case Alam & Khan (1966-68), advised ministers including Anthony Crosland, managed Bovis then Barratt, served as Hackney Labour councillor, Liberty council member and TV presenter. In 2005 he founded Asylum Justice for asylum-seeker representation. He married teacher Elizabeth James in 1966; died aged 89 on 30 November 2025, survived by children Katharine, Owen and granddaughter Lana.

articles.title: Downing Street vows to force employment rights bill through Lords
articles.trailText: No more concessions, says minister after legislation was thwarted in upper house despite manifesto climbdown
articles.summary: After Conservative and cross-bench Lords blocked the government’s employment rights bill over lifting the unfair dismissal compensation cap, Downing Street insists no more concessions and will compel another Lords vote next week. The compromise deal with unions reduced the qualifying period for unfair dismissal protection from two years to six months in exchange for cap removal. Ministers warn peers that further obstruction risks a constitutional showdown – including potential use of the 1911 Parliament Act – as the bill returns to the Commons Monday and the Lords Tuesday to secure its passage before Christmas.

articles.title: Starmer and hardline governments risk creating ‘hierarchy of people’ by constraining human rights
articles.trailText: Human rights official says politicians are playing into the hands of the populist right as they seek to tackle migration
articles.summary: Michael O’Flaherty, Council of Europe human rights commissioner, warns that Keir Starmer and Europe’s hardline governments risk creating a “hierarchy of people” by narrowing ECHR rights to curb migration. Twenty-seven states—including the UK, Hungary and Italy—signed an unofficial statement urging constraints on Articles 3 and 8 to allow Rwanda-style deals and deportation of foreign criminals. Critics such as Lord Dubs, Shami Chakrabarti and Liberty argue this undermines human rights universality and threatens detainees, protesters and prisoners. Supporters like Lord Hain favour treaty reinterpretation, while foreign secretary Yvette Cooper won’t rule out Channel pushbacks. Labour remains committed to the ECHR amid immigration-driven polling woes.

articles.title: Will Labour’s move to limit ECHR deter the far right or alienate progressive voters?
articles.trailText: Previously sceptical MPs now want to modernise human rights law to prevent an overreach of the law and losing to the far right
articles.summary: Once sceptical voices like Shabana Mahmood, now home secretary, backed David Lammy and AG Richard Hermer in Strasbourg to seek an ECHR declaration narrowing “inhuman or degrading treatment” and curbing family‐life rights in domestic courts. Labour argues this will unblock deportations of violent offenders and blunt far‐right attacks without quitting the convention under Keir Starmer. Critics warn this reform‐or‐die approach may alienate progressive voters and still fall short of assuaging anti‐immigration sentiment.

articles.title: What does UK want to change about human rights law – and will it happen?
articles.trailText: Ministers in Strasbourg have been discussing the European Convention on Human Rights and how it affects migration
articles.summary: UK ministers in Strasbourg pressed for reinterpretation of the European Convention on Human Rights to ease deportation of unauthorised migrants, focusing on articles 3 (ban on torture) and 8 (family life). At an informal Council of Europe meeting, 27 of 46 states signed a statement to amend removal rules, smuggling measures and “returns hubs.” Migration cases remain a small share of ECHR appeals. Technical talks run Jan–Feb ahead of a May 2025 summit in Moldova to agree a political declaration or binding decision. Starmer aims to reform ECHR practice rather than withdraw amid Conservative and Reform UK pressure.

articles.title: Linda Reynolds vows to fight until ‘bitter end’ to defend reputation in Brittany Higgins saga
articles.trailText: Former Liberal senator says ‘justice is not cheap’ and ‘if I lose everything, it will have been worth it’
articles.summary: Ex-senator Linda Reynolds told ABC she’ll fight “to the bitter end” after courts cleared her of covering up Brittany Higgins’s 2019 rape allegation. Reynolds won A$315,000 in defamation damages from Higgins—who faces bankruptcy proceedings to pay A$1m in costs—and is suing the Commonwealth over Higgins’s A$2.4m settlement. She cites rulings that she never disputed the rape, that AFP involvement and welfare support were proper, and that Bruce Lehrmann’s criminal trial was abandoned after juror misconduct—though a civil court later found him liable. Reynolds blames political rivals and media for a “fabricated scandal” and insists the cost is worth clearing her name.

articles.title: Starmer urges Europe’s leaders to curb ECHR to halt rise of far right
articles.trailText: Exclusive: PM calls for members of European convention on human rights to allow tougher action to protect borders
articles.summary: On the eve of a Council of Europe summit in Strasbourg, UK PM Keir Starmer and Danish leader Mette Frederiksen called for modernising the European Convention on Human Rights so member states can tighten border controls and curb the populist right. They propose clarifying Article 8 (family life) to limit asylum challenges and raising thresholds under Article 3 (prohibition of torture) to ease deportations. Critics—including human-rights advocates, Labour peers and celebrities—warn changes could erode protections for the vulnerable. The UK aims to mirror Denmark’s hard-line asylum model, add safe legal routes and legislate domestic ECHR reinterpretation.

articles.title: Principled reasons to cut the number of jury trials | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Retired judge Michael Harris says we should not reject reform, we should refine it. Christian Mole says the system is blighted by inefficiency
articles.summary: Retired judge Michael Harris argues cutting jury trials is justified: juries, used in few democracies, are costly, time-consuming, and conflict with the principle that verdicts be accompanied by reasons—without which appeals focus on judges’ directions, not the verdict rationale. He proposes replacing juries with panels of judges, lawyers, specialists or trained lay members, guarding against bias and offering expertise. Christian Mole, reflecting his own jury service, highlights chronic delays, idle waiting and retrials, underlining the system’s inefficiency and expense.

articles.title: Stephen Fry and Joanna Lumley among celebrities urging UK not to weaken torture protections
articles.trailText: Public figures sign letter saying plan to reinterpret ECHR for asylum seekers is ‘affront to us all’ and a threat to security
articles.summary: Actors Stephen Fry, Joanna Lumley, Michael Palin and 18 others—including Julian Barnes and Adrian Lester—have written to PM Keir Starmer and Justice Secretary David Lammy urging them to drop plans to reinterpret Article 3 of the ECHR to curb torture protections for asylum seekers. Ahead of a Council of Europe summit in Strasbourg, the letter, coordinated by Freedom From Torture, warns that weakening the absolute ban on torture is “an affront to us all and a threat to security,” risks undermining Britain’s human rights legacy and could embolden authoritarian regimes. Ministers argue ECHR implementation must evolve to address modern migration, but campaigners insist Article 3 is non-derogable.

articles.title: Rights groups warn against UK plans to weaken torture protections in ECHR
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Ministers face pushback over potential changes to asylum seekers’ rights before Council of Europe meeting
articles.summary: At a Council of Europe summit this week, Justice Secretary David Lammy is poised to back UK proposals to narrow the scope of ECHR Articles 3 and 8, tightening asylum policy by limiting ‘inhuman or degrading treatment’ grounds and recalibrating family-life rights in removal cases. The Home Office argues Article 3 protections have expanded via mental-health claims, warranting reform. Human rights NGOs—including Freedom from Torture and Amnesty International—warn that weakening the absolute ban on torture or rebalancing family rights risks eroding universal protections and could prompt a global backlash. The government says it remains committed to the ECHR while seeking procedural clarity for Article 8.

articles.title: ‘A move towards an authoritarian state’: what those with trial experience think of removing juries
articles.trailText: David Lammy plans to cut the number of jury trials in England and Wales. A defendant, a victim, a barrister, a KC, a judge and a juror have concerns
articles.summary: Justice secretary David Lammy will limit jury trials in England & Wales to indictable-only offences and either-way cases with sentences above three years, sparking an outcry across the justice system. Defendant Abrar Javid recounts how an all-white jury in his Rotherham disorder trial delivered a fair verdict, restoring his faith. Coercive control victim Dorothy worries magistrates lack the nuance jurors provide. KCs Keir Monteith and Mark Fenhalls condemn the reforms as unconstitutional, racially biased and authoritarian. Retired judge Chris Kinch highlights jurors’ ability to spot holes judges miss; juror Adam lauds accountability. Critics argue backlogs demand efficiency, not fewer juries.

articles.title: UK workers will get unfair dismissal rights after six months from 1 January 2027
articles.trailText: Angela Rayner drops plan to force earlier implementation after talks, says source, with start date to be announced in Commons
articles.summary: Ministers pledge to implement unfair dismissal protections after six months’ service from 1 January 2027, replacing the current two-year qualifying period. The deal, brokered by Angela Rayner and Business Secretary Peter Kyle, drops planned day-one rights. Workers employed from July 2026 with six months’ tenure will qualify immediately. The Employment Rights Bill, due back in the Lords, also lifts compensation caps, extends rights to zero-hours and variable-contract staff, and strengthens union access—a significant Labour victory amid peer opposition.

articles.title: What juries can do that professional judges can’t | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Jurors bring a humane, rounded perspective to the system, says Simeon Wallis . Plus letters from Diana Good and Francis FitzGibbon KC
articles.summary: In three letters responding to Simon Jenkins, barristers and a part-time judge defend juries as a vital democratic safeguard in serious criminal cases. They argue jurors bring a humane, proportionate and conscience-driven perspective that professional judges—bound by legal precedent and courtroom routine—may lack. They stress juries only decide guilt while judges handle sentencing, and attribute court delays to chronic underfunding, not jury trials. Contributors call to retain trial by jury and consider broader citizen assemblies for civic participation.

articles.title: Letter: Sir Geoffrey Bindman obituary
articles.trailText: Jeremy Corbyn writes: He dedicated his life to protecting the freedoms of ordinary people
articles.summary: Sir Geoffrey Bindman, renowned human rights barrister, dedicated over six decades to defending civil liberties and the underdog. Founder of a firm that became the go-to for justice causes, he supported clients through personal hells with characteristic warmth and empathy. He represented Chilean torture survivors in Pinochet’s extradition case, famously quipping that a housebound legal limbo was its own harsh punishment. A steadfast advocate, known as a principled risk-taker, he championed freedom of expression and due process across landmark cases, shaping UK human rights law. Bindman insisted truth underpinned all justice and stood up for ordinary people’s freedoms regardless of risk, as recalled by Jeremy Corbyn.

articles.title: Why Lammy wants to scrap some jury trials – and the arguments against
articles.trailText: Justice secretary says record backlog is failing victims and defendants, but there are concerns about lack of diversity among judges
articles.summary: Justice secretary David Lammy will remove jury trials for offences with likely sentences under three years and complex fraud/financial cases, diverting them to judge-only courts or enhanced magistrates (sentences up to 18–24 months). A crown courts backlog of almost 80,000 cases, rising to 100,000, drives this reform aimed at reducing delays harming victims and witnesses. Based on Brian Leveson’s recommendations, the plans guarantee full jury trials for serious indictable offences such as rape, murder, aggravated burglary and people trafficking. Critics warn it undermines Magna Carta rights, risks miscarriages of justice given judicial homogeneity, weakens conscience acquittals, and ignores underfunding and systemic inefficiencies as root causes.

articles.title: David Lammy expected to water down plans to scrap most jury trials
articles.trailText: Justice secretary suggests he will stick to Leveson’s recommended three-year sentence threshold in England and Wales, after ‘cabinet feedback’
articles.summary: After a leaked memo proposed restricting jury trials to offences with potential sentences above five years, Justice Secretary David Lammy is set to follow Sir Brian Leveson’s recommendation, reserving juries for charges likely to yield sentences over three years. Jury trials would be confined to murder, rape, manslaughter and serious crimes, with lesser 'either-way' offences such as assault, theft and handling stolen goods diverted to magistrates' courts or a new judge-only bench division. Lammy cites a 100,000-case backlog and Cabinet feedback. The plan faces pushback from MPs, the Bar Council, Criminal Bar Association, Law Society and advocates warning of fairness and racial bias risks.

articles.title: Lammy lambasts ‘courts emergency’ as he prepares to face MPs over plans to slash jury trials
articles.trailText: Justice secretary expected to announce plans to tackle backlog of cases as he says system has been pushed to brink of collapse
articles.summary: David Lammy has declared a courts emergency in England and Wales, warning of a backlog of 78,000 Crown court cases set to surpass 100,000 by 2028 and plans to reserve jury trials for serious offences such as murder, rape and manslaughter with sentences over five years. Leaked MoJ proposals would shift lesser either-way, technical fraud and financial cases to judge-only trials or a new bench-division model with a judge plus two lay magistrates. After opposition from the Bar Council, Criminal Bar Association and civil rights advocates, Lammy paused rollout. He will follow Sir Brian Leveson’s recommendations and invest £550m in victims’ services over three years.

articles.title: Plan to reduce jury trials an ‘irremediable error’, lawyers say in MoJ letter
articles.trailText: More than 100 lawyers have accused the Ministry of Justice of ignoring the legal profession’s objections
articles.summary: Over 100 lawyers, including 23 King’s Counsel, have warned the Ministry of Justice that its plan to limit jury trials—introducing judge-alone trials for most offences and reserving juries for public interest cases with sentences over five years—constitutes an "irremediable error." They argue Leveson-based changes won’t cut the 78,000-case backlog, erode an ancient right, and undermine trust. The Criminal Bar Association warns removing juries will damage social cohesion and fail to filter prejudice. The MoJ says no final decision has been taken and emphasizes the need to clear the backlog harming victims and witnesses.

articles.title: Government to ditch day-one unfair dismissal policy from workers’ rights bill
articles.trailText: Flagship Labour plan to be replaced with six-month threshold after Peter Kyle vows to not let businesses ‘lose’ under new law
articles.summary: Labour’s government has abandoned its manifesto pledge to grant day-one unfair dismissal rights, replacing it with a six-month qualifying period. Business Secretary Peter Kyle brokered a deal with six major business groups and union leaders to unblock the workers’ rights bill, scrapping proposals for a nine-month probation and cutting the two-year dismissal threshold. The TUC prioritized securing day-one sick pay, but leftwing MPs and Unite leader Sharon Graham decried the U-turn as a betrayal of promised worker protections.

articles.title: Labour’s plan to slash jury trials will create more miscarriages of justice, say critics
articles.trailText: Leading barrister and pressure groups say move would lead to more unfairness for Black, Asian and minority ethnic defendants
articles.summary: Labour plans by David Lammy to restrict jury trials to offences attracting 5-plus-year sentences, shifting most trials to judges and expanded magistrate powers. Critics warn this undermines his own 2017 review showing juries filter bias—citing higher conviction rates for Black, Asian and other minority defendants in magistrates courts (for every 100 white men, 208 Black men and 193 Asian men jailed for sexual offences). Barrister Keir Monteith KC, Justice CEO Fiona Rutherford, Appeal co-director Matt Foot and peer Shami Chakrabarti argue reduced diversity on benches risks more miscarriages of justice. Starmer’s 1992 writing defended juries as a check on state power; MoJ says no final decision.

articles.title: ‘Unavoidably unfair’: the secret courts system hearing part of Palestine Action case
articles.trailText: The CMP system means Huda Ammori will not be allowed to know what allegations were made against her
articles.summary: Challenge to the ban on Palestine Action will be partly heard under the secret closed material procedure (CMP), meaning co-founder Huda Ammori and her lawyers will be excluded from parts of the hearing and barred from knowing evidence or allegations against her. Special advocates represent her in secret but cannot disclose details, undermining rebuttal. Critics including long-serving special advocate Angus McCullough KC and former judges call CMPs inherently unfair. Extended by the 2013 Justice and Security Act, CMPs balance national security against fair trial rights; a recent expert report urged stricter necessity tests and greater judicial discretion to curb secrecy.

articles.title: David Lammy considers scrapping jury trials for all but the most serious cases
articles.trailText: Senior lawyers criticise justice secretary’s radical plan for England and Wales, saying it could ‘destroy justice as we know it’
articles.summary: Justice Secretary David Lammy has proposed eliminating jury trials in England and Wales for all offences except murder, manslaughter, rape and other public interest crimes carrying sentences over five years. Under plans to create a Crown Court Bench Division, single judges would try fraud, financial and most serious non-fatal offences to tackle a 78,000-case backlog. Senior lawyers, including the Law Society and Criminal Bar Association, warn the measure exceeds Leveson review recommendations, threatens lay participation, risks fairness and would not reduce delays. The MoJ says no final decision has been made.

articles.title: It’s not jury trials that have left Britain’s justice system in crisis | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: The introduction of an intermediary court that has not been properly piloted is not the answer when other inefficiencies plaguing the system could be tackled first, says Barbara Mills of the Bar Council
articles.summary: Barbara Mills of the Bar Council criticizes plans to introduce the Crown Court Bench Division (CCBD), an intermediary court from the Leveson review, arguing it’s a resource-intensive, unpiloted change unlikely to reduce the 80,000-case backlog by 2029. She urges the government to improve existing crown court infrastructure, prisoner escort and custody services, and court technology first. Empty courtrooms, delays and underfunding—not jury trials—are the real causes of delay and mistrust. Any major overhaul should be modelled and piloted to maintain confidence in Britain’s justice system. Mills warns that skipping pilot stages risks eroding public trust in legal traditions.

articles.title: Woman denied indefinite leave to remain in UK under Windrush scheme wins appeal
articles.trailText: Home Office ordered to reconsider case of Jeanell Hippolyte, whose father and brother were granted ILR
articles.summary: The Court of Appeal has ruled that the Home Office must reconsider Jeanell Hippolyte’s bid for indefinite leave to remain under the Windrush scheme, despite her not meeting its strict residency terms. Hippolyte, a Saint Lucian national who first arrived in the UK aged 17 in 2000, was unaware her father held ILR and saw her applications refused in 2021 and 2023. Lord Justice Singh held her close ties fall within the scheme’s spirit, instructing officials to exercise their discretionary power, a decision with potential precedent for similar borderline cases.

articles.title: Why does MoJ want to curtail jury trials in England and Wales?
articles.trailText: Right to trial by jury seen as bedrock of justice system but Sir Brian Leveson says court backlogs could lead to ‘total system collapse’
articles.summary: Facing record court backlogs risking system collapse, the MoJ under Sarah Sackman will implement Sir Brian Leveson’s July proposals to shift thousands of England and Wales criminal cases from juries to judges and magistrates. Key measures include a new crown-court bench division (judge plus two magistrates) for ‘either-way’ offences, reclassifying some crimes to magistrates’ courts, judge-only trials for serious fraud, and removing jury rights in certain assaults, harassment and abduction cases. Saved crown-court days are estimated at 9,000 annually, though backlog clearance may exceed five years. Critics—Criminal Bar, Bar Council, Law Society—warn of eroding jury traditions, diversity risks and urged more funding.

articles.title: MoJ to remove right to trial by jury for thousands of cases in controversial overhaul
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Courts minister says change needed to stop criminals opting for juries to delay cases, sometimes by years, and clear huge backlog
articles.summary: The Ministry of Justice will strip the right to jury trials from thousands of either-way offences—mostly non-violent thefts and intermediate fraud—by creating a judge-only Crown Court division to clear an 80,000-case backlog by 2029. Courts minister Sarah Sackman, citing Sir Brian Leveson’s review, says criminals exploit jury elections to delay proceedings for years while victims wait up to four years for trial. Critics, including 90% of the Criminal Bar, the judiciary and racial equality groups, warn the move could erode public trust and worsen minority under-representation.

articles.title: Sir Geoffrey Bindman obituary
articles.trailText: Human rights lawyer who helped to expand Britain’s Race Relations Act and investigated apartheid in South Africa
articles.summary: Sir Geoffrey Bindman (1933–2025) was a British human rights solicitor whose career shaped race equality and international justice. From 1965 he partnered at Lawford & Co and advised the Race Relations Board (1966–76) and Commission for Racial Equality (1976–83), influencing the 1968 and 1976 Race Relations Acts. He co-founded Camden Community Law Centre (1973), established Bindmans LLP (1974) and defended Private Eye (1969–84). His missions ranged from apartheid South Africa—editing South Africa and the Rule of Law (1988)—to Uganda and Chile. Knighted in 2007, he taught at UCL and LSBU, became honorary QC in 2011 and collected radical pamphlets.

articles.title: Willing states must act to save international legal order, warns top academic
articles.trailText: Yale professor says wars in Ukraine and Gaza and threats from Donald Trump risk the ‘total collapse’ of the global courts system
articles.summary: Yale law professor Oona Hathaway warns that the postwar international legal order, anchored by the prohibition on conquest, faces existential threats from Russia’s Ukraine invasion, China’s South China Sea seizures, conflicts in Gaza, and US delegitimization under Trump. She frames the prohibition of forceful conquest as the 'foundational norm' now imperiled. She notes ICJ compliance has dropped to ~50%, endangering civilian protections and the system’s authority. With the UNSC unable to enforce judgments, Hathaway proposes forming state coalitions to suspend non-compliant members from UN bodies, expand the Hague Group to uphold all ICJ and ICC rulings, and leverage collective measures to shore up compliance.

articles.title: Bar Council calls for legal aid for all family court cases involving domestic abuse
articles.trailText: Only 15% of families are eligible for legal aid which has led to huge swathes of UK becoming ‘legal advice deserts’, body says
articles.summary: The Bar Council, representing 18,000 barristers, urges all family court cases involving domestic abuse to be covered by legal aid and for means testing to be removed for alleged victims and survivors. With only 15% of families currently eligible, many areas have become ‘legal advice deserts’, forcing victims to self-represent. Its policy paper recommends boosting family law aid, funding pathfinder and family drug and alcohol courts, supporting Domestic Abuse Protection Orders and Notices, offering perpetrator programmes post-hearing, and upgrading court security and facilities. It argues stronger family justice is key to tackling violence against women and girls.

articles.title: Jailed UK climate protesters facing conditions reserved for extremists on release
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Just Stop Oil activist was banned from attending gatherings, including meeting a friend in a cafe, without permission
articles.summary: Just Stop Oil activist Ella Ward (22) and other jailed UK climate protesters were released on licence conditions originally reserved for extremist offenders, including bans on attending gatherings (except worship), meeting friends in cafes and contributing to websites without probation approval. After Ward’s judicial review, the Ministry of Justice dropped those extremism-linked restrictions. Lawyers and campaigners warn these non-standard conditions unduly restrict free speech and assembly, calling on HMPPS to review their use against peaceful demonstrators.

articles.title: Revealed: Qatar-linked intelligence operation targeted ICC prosecutor’s alleged victim
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Woman who accused Karim Khan of misconduct was subject of covert operation involving two British private intelligence firms
articles.summary: The Guardian reveals that Qatar’s diplomatic unit commissioned London-based Highgate, with partner Elicius Intelligence, to spy on the ICC staffer who accused prosecutor Karim Khan of sexual misconduct. Leaked files show the firms collected her passport, flight data, child’s birth certificate, family details and hacked passwords, and sought links to Israeli intelligence to undermine her claims. Khan, who denied abuse and stepped aside pending a UN inquiry, says the allegations form part of a smear campaign following his Gaza arrest warrants for Netanyahu. Highgate denies acting against individuals.

articles.title: AI firm wins high court ruling after photo agency’s copyright claim
articles.trailText: Ruling in case brought by Getty Images against Stability AI is seen as a blow to copyright owners
articles.summary: Stability AI, co-founded by Avatar’s James Cameron, won a UK High Court ruling rejecting Getty Images’ copyright suit over training data, with Mrs Justice Joanna Smith finding Stable Diffusion neither stores nor reproduces Getty’s works and thus isn’t an ‘infringing copy.’ Getty dropped core copyright claims for jurisdictional reasons but maintained trademark claims over watermarked outputs, securing limited success. The verdict intensifies debate over the UK’s secondary copyright framework, fuels government consultations on a text-and-data-mining exception, and urges stronger transparency rules for AI training data.

articles.title: Putting children’s safety first will protect them from abusive parents | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to a change in the law that repeals the presumption of parental involvement in England and Wales, and places child safety above all else
articles.summary: Readers welcome the repeal of the presumption of parental involvement in England and Wales, hailing it a long-overdue win for children facing domestic abuse. Many share horror at family courts forcing contact with abusive fathers and relief that child safety and best interests now override contact at any cost. They describe discredited “parental alienation” claims used to protect abusers, note court systems that traumatized mothers, and warn of loving non-abusive fathers facing cost barriers under the new presumption. Comparisons with Canada’s child-centred approach underscore the shift towards prioritising children’s rights over parental rights.

articles.title: ‘Dangerously outdated’: high court overturns ruling implying domestic violence would not affect children
articles.trailText: Judge describes earlier decision in case at family court as a ‘wrong turn’ and says allegations go to heart of case
articles.summary: In a ruling the High Court (Mr Justice Garrido KC) overturned Recorder Forshaw KC’s refusal of a fact-finding hearing in a 2024 family case where a mother alleged seven rapes by the father (2009–2020) alongside stalking, threats of revenge pornography, assault and brake-pad removal (possible attempted murder). On appeal, the mother’s counsel argued such severe abuse cannot be dismissed as merely “historical” or irrelevant to child welfare. Garrido deemed the lower decision a “wrong turn” and ordered the hearing, stressing that proof of abuse is essential to assess the children’s risk. A report shows domestic abuse features in 87% of family cases but influences only 42% of rulings; advocates call for mandatory judicial training.

articles.title: Sex offenders to be denied parental responsibility for children born of rape
articles.trailText: New law ‘puts needs of survivors above the needs of rapists’, says MP Natalie Fleet, who campaigned for the change
articles.summary: In England and Wales, a government-backed amendment to the Victims and Courts Bill will automatically strip sex offenders of parental responsibility for any child conceived through rape and for serious sexual offences against minors, effective upon sentencing without family court approval. Where conception by rape wasn’t established criminally, crown courts must notify local authorities to seek the mother’s consent for proceedings. Bolsover MP Natalie Fleet, drawing on her own experience of rape, campaigned successfully for this reform, supported by Deputy PM David Lammy and minister Alex Davies-Jones, as part of measures to protect survivors and children and overhaul family-law presumptions.

articles.title: Pets on flights can be classed as baggage, top EU court rules
articles.trailText: European court of justice asked to intervene after dog was lost on journey from Buenos Aires to Barcelona
articles.summary: Europe’s highest court, the ECJ, ruled pets transported by airlines are legally baggage under the Montréal convention, limiting compensation to lost luggage levels absent special value declarations. The case arose after Iberia accepted liability for losing Mona, a dog that escaped while being loaded from Buenos Aires to Barcelona, but contested a €5,000 non-material damage claim. The court found no special declaration was made, capping liability at €1,578.82. The judgment, referred by a Spanish court, sets a precedent on pet travel liability. Critics say airlines never accept special declarations for animals in the hold.

articles.title: EHRC drops interim trans advice and urges ministers to act fast to approve its guidance
articles.trailText: Equalities watchdog removes interim response to supreme court ruling on legal definition of a woman from its website
articles.summary: Following the Supreme Court’s April ruling that ‘woman’ refers to biological sex, the Equality and Human Rights Commission has removed interim guidance instructing institutions to bar trans people from gender-segregated spaces. It now advises organisations to seek specialist legal advice until its statutory code—sent to ministers in September—is approved. Campaigners and the Council of Europe’s human rights commissioner warned the interim advice risked widespread exclusion of trans people; the Good Law Project has a court challenge pending. EHRC chair Kishwer Falkner urges minister Bridget Phillipson to fast-track the 300-page guidance.

articles.title: Exiled Hong Kong dissidents fear UK plan to restart extraditions will put them in danger
articles.trailText: Legislative change comes five years after treaty suspended in response to city’s crackdown on pro-democracy activists
articles.summary: UK has amended extradition law to redesignate Hong Kong as a non-treaty state, enabling case-by-case extradition requests revoked in 2019 after Beijing’s national security law crackdown. While Home Office insists on “strict legal safeguards”, dissidents warn Hong Kong authorities will exploit any pretext to pursue political targets. Exiled activists, including BNO passport holders, demand binding assurances against future politically motivated extraditions, citing past abuse of charges in Jimmy Lai’s trial. Critics link timing to UK-China trade talks and urge a dedicated appeal mechanism. UK courts, they say, cannot alone guard against hostile arrest warrants issued on UK soil.

articles.title: Human rights official urges UK to review laws after Palestine Action placard arrests
articles.trailText: Counter-terror laws must not place unnecessary limits on ‘fundamental rights’, Michael O’Flaherty tells Shabana Mahmood
articles.summary: Council of Europe human rights commissioner Michael O’Flaherty has urged home secretary Shabana Mahmood to review UK protest laws after hundreds were arrested under the July 5 Palestine Action ban for holding pro-Palestine placards. He warned that new offences in the Crime and Policing Bill criminalizing concealed identity at protests, alongside expanded powers in recent protest legislation, risk overpolicing and undue limits on peaceful assembly and expression. O’Flaherty called for retrospective case reviews and a comprehensive audit of protest laws against human rights obligations. International rights groups accuse Western states of using counter-terror and antisemitism laws to curb dissent.

articles.title: Linda Reynolds pursues bankruptcy proceedings against Brittany Higgins after defamation win
articles.trailText: Former Liberal senator launches claim in effort to obtain more than $1m in damages and legal costs
articles.summary: Former WA Liberal senator Linda Reynolds has launched bankruptcy proceedings against ex-staffer Brittany Higgins and her husband, David Sharaz, seeking more than A$1 million in damages and legal costs after an August defamation victory. Justice Paul Tottle ordered Higgins to pay $315,000 plus $26,109 interest and 80% of Reynolds’ legal fees, finding Higgins’ July 2023 Instagram story defamatory and Sharaz jointly liable for his role in a defamatory tweet. Higgins and Sharaz have filed an appeal. The case ties back to Higgins’ 2021 sexual assault allegations against a colleague in Reynolds’ office, with related defamation rulings and appeals involving Bruce Lehrmann ongoing.

articles.title: Tackling the lack of Black talent in the legal system | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: We need to stop pretending the field is level and talk about what real equity looks like, says Pauline Campbell
articles.summary: In her letter Pauline Campbell welcomes the Bar Council’s use of the Equality Act to fund paid internships for Black students via the 10,000 Black Interns programme, aimed at redressing chronic underrepresentation at senior levels such as king’s counsel. She notes swift backlash from Reform UK MP Rupert Lowe and the Spectator, cites a Legal Services Board warning, a 1% Study on partners, Nuffield’s 60% extra-CVs finding and Bar Standards Board pupillage disparities, and calls for real equity.

articles.title: Could a landmark court decision undermine the right to peacefully protest in NSW?
articles.trailText: Human rights advocates fear new ruling could deter people from using system designed to facilitate protests – and expose them to risk of criminal charges
articles.summary: NSW Court of Appeal deemed attending a court-prohibited protest itself criminal, in a decision that blocked a pro-Palestine march to the Sydney Opera House. Previously, breaking location bans only risked obstruction or move-on charges; now mere presence exposes demonstrators to contempt of court or unlawful assembly charges. Critics warn this will deter use of the 1979 “form 1” notice regime designed to facilitate peaceful assembly, undermining free-speech safeguards. Police say they expect form 1s to continue but civil liberties groups and organisers fear a chilling effect and plan high-court challenges over constitutional rights.

articles.title: Why has the UK dropped its trial of two alleged China spies?
articles.trailText: Prosecutor hinted at lack of backing from Downing Street but legal experts argue prosecution was still possible
articles.summary: DPP Stephen Parkinson disclosed the CPS abandoned its October trial of Christopher Cash and Christopher Berry, accused of spying for China, after Downing Street failed to provide a witness statement affirming China posed a current threat to UK national security. July case law narrowed the Official Secrets Act’s “enemy” definition to real-time threats. Officials under both Conservative and Labour governments balked at the assertion. Legal experts suggest the CPS was overly cautious. Cash, a former parliamentary researcher, and Berry deny wrongdoing, insisting they shared only public-domain material.

articles.title: Legal experts question reasoning behind CPS dropping China ‘spies’ case
articles.trailText: Ex-DPP Ken Macdonald says prosecutors may have been ‘over-fussy’ in seeking further assurances from government
articles.summary: Following new case law on the 1911 Official Secrets Act’s “enemy” test, the CPS unexpectedly dropped espionage charges against ex-MP researcher Christopher Cash and associate Christopher Berry, accused of spying for China from 2021-23. DPP Stephen Parkinson said a July 2024 ruling required explicit government assurance that China posed a national security threat, which prosecutors couldn’t secure. Former DPP Ken Macdonald and ex-CPS lawyer Nick Vamos criticized the decision as “over-fussy” or a prosecutorial misstep. The charges were abandoned amid political finger-pointing by Labour and the Conservatives.

articles.title: Tory plan to scrap judge-led Sentencing Council criticised as ‘bonkers’
articles.trailText: Ex-Conservative ministers denounce Robert Jenrick’s intention to abolish body that develops court guidelines
articles.summary: Robert Jenrick will propose abolishing the independent Sentencing Council, transferring guideline-setting from judges to the lord chancellor and Ministry of Justice to enforce tougher sentences. Former Tory ministers including Dominic Grieve and Bob Neill denounce the plan as “bonkers,” unimplementable and dangerous, warning it would exacerbate prison overcrowding and risk system collapse. Established in 2010 to ensure consistent, expert-led sentencing, the council’s critics accuse it of watering down parliamentary intent on serious crimes. Labour MPs and legal experts call the move a politicisation of justice and a cynical gimmick.

articles.title: Robin Shaw obituary
articles.trailText: Unflappable defamation lawyer who secured landmark victories for freedom of speech in London’s libel courts
articles.summary: Robin Shaw, 66, was an unflappable London defamation lawyer whose landmark victories shaped free speech law. Over four decades he defended the Guardian, Mirror, Telegraph and Private Eye (with Ian Hislop), orchestrating wins in high-stakes trials—most notably quashing Noel Clarke’s £10m libel claim in 2023—and overturning BBC privacy injunctions for HarperCollins (Top Gear’s Ben Collins) and Andrew Marr. A partner at Davenport Lyons (1995–2014), later Gordon Dadds and Wiggin, he combined encyclopedic legal acumen with dry wit. Married to barrister Rupina Ahluwalia, he died after cancer treatment.

articles.title: Trump’s crackdown on lawyers shows ‘no place is immune’, says US bar chief
articles.trailText: Michelle Behnke says lawyers from around the world have given support as ABA challenges ‘policy of intimidation’
articles.summary: Trump’s administration has imposed security-clearance terminations, contract bans and building-access restrictions on lawyers and firms representing clients opposed to the president, prompting the ABA under president Michelle Behnke to file a federal suit attacking this “policy of intimidation.” Speaking in London, Behnke warned that “no place is immune,” praised international lawyers’ solidarity and said the reversal of roles underscored the global peril to the rule of law. She stressed diversity, equity and inclusion as central to justice and invoked Shakespeare on anarchy: “First kill all the lawyers.”

articles.title: How we can reform community sentencing | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: A plan to name and shame people doing community service is wrong, says Ruth Windle . Plus a letter from Peter Fellows
articles.summary: Letters debate community sentencing reforms: Ruth Windle argues naming and shaming offenders is medieval, humiliates those already sentenced, fuels resentment and undermines rehabilitation and social cohesion. She contends confidence in community orders stems from providing offenders with purposeful contributions to local communities. Peter Fellows proposes adopting a motoring-style demerit system for low-level crimes: offences accrue points proportional to seriousness, with 12 points within three years triggering a 12-month custodial term, thereby deterring repeat offending and easing court workloads.

articles.title: Letter: Hazel Fox obituary
articles.trailText: David M Ong: With characteristic generosity, Hazel Fox invited me to the conference for nothing.
articles.summary: David M Ong recalls how legal scholar Hazel Fox, while organizing a BIICL conference in the late 1980s on joint development of offshore oil and gas, invited him as a Hull University master’s student free of charge. Fox and her small research team drafted a pioneering model bilateral agreement that eased sovereignty disputes over shared deposits, establishing a lasting cooperative framework for resource‐extraction law.

articles.title: Ministers plan to allow naming and shaming of offenders completing community sentences
articles.trailText: Exclusive: critics say the move, part of the sentencing bill for England and Wales, would bring shame upon families of offenders
articles.summary: Under a new sentencing bill in England and Wales, probation officers would gain legal powers to photograph and publish names and images of offenders completing unpaid community work (‘community payback’), aiming to boost public confidence in non-custodial sentences. Critics—including probation inspectors, union leaders and charities—warn the measures risk humiliating offenders’ families, deterring participation, hampering rehabilitation and exacerbating marginalisation. The government says the policy will increase transparency as unpaid work orders expand to alleviate prison overcrowding, with exemptions for vulnerable individuals to be defined in subsequent legislation.

articles.title: Crown court backlog in England and Wales hits new record of almost 80,000 cases
articles.trailText: Ministry of Justice data shows 10% increase in open cases as waiting times for trial dates reach up to four years
articles.summary: Ministry of Justice data show England and Wales' crown court backlog rose 10% year-on-year to 78,329 open cases at June, with median case age up 10% and 19,164 cases over a year old. Awaiting trials span up to four years, with some listings as late as October 2029. Rising demand—30,000 new cases quarterly—and jumps in sexual offences (13%), rape (21%), violence and drug crimes are outpacing capacity. Ministers weigh Sir Brian Leveson's proposals—limiting jury trials, judge-only courts—and record investment to tackle infrastructure decay and shuttered courtrooms.

articles.title: ‘Maggots raining down’: survey lays bare dire state of courts in England and Wales
articles.trailText: Asbestos and faeces flooding cells also among problems contributing to huge backlog in cases, Law Society finds
articles.summary: A Law Society survey of nearly 300 solicitors exposes dilapidated courts in England and Wales: reports of asbestos, mould, decaying seagulls, maggots and cells flooding with excrement, alongside failing air-conditioning, broken toilets and unreliable technology. 63% experienced case delays, contributing to a crown court backlog of over 76,957 cases and two-thirds of family care matters exceeding the 26-week limit. Only 17% rated court buildings largely fit for purpose, while one in five deemed technology totally unfit. Raac concrete faults and poor accessibility heighten injustice. The Society urges a £1.3bn maintenance invest­ment; MoJ cites recent funding boosts.

articles.title: Judge quashes Home Office’s decision on US extradition of vulnerable man
articles.trailText: Portugal has also made extradition request for Diogo Santos Coelho, who is facing cybercrime charges
articles.summary: A high court quashed the Home Office’s decision to extradite 25-year-old Portuguese national Diogo Santos Coelho to the US on cybercrime charges linked to RaidForums—crimes carrying a potential 52-year sentence—after finding his autism, mental-health vulnerabilities, modern-slavery exploitation, high suicide risk and grooming from age 14 were ignored. The judge ruled the home secretary must reconsider US versus Portuguese requests, allowing Coelho and both states to make representations, and weigh his proximity to family, legal systems and support before prioritising his consented extradition to Portugal.

articles.title: Partner at top libel firm hired ‘in furtherance of fraud’, tribunal rules
articles.trailText: Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal issues decision in case against Claire Gill, a partner at Carter-Ruck, over legal threats on behalf of client
articles.summary: Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal rules Carter-Ruck partner Claire Gill’s 2017 retainer for OneCoin was ‘in furtherance of fraud’ when she sent an improper litigation threat to victim Jen McAdam over YouTube videos. Although no suit was filed, the SRA is prosecuting Gill. SDT, which can impose unlimited fines or disbar solicitors, approved disclosure of documents citing Ignatova’s fugitive status and asset freeze. Carter-Ruck insists Gill acted in good faith. Gill seeks summary dismissal; next hearing is December amid debates over SLAPP threats by English lawyers.

articles.title: Conor Gearty obituary
articles.trailText: A skilled and persuasive human rights lawyer who fought for civil liberties in the face of over-reaching anti-terror law
articles.summary: Conor Gearty (1957–2025) was an Irish-born human rights lawyer and academic who became a leading authority on counter-terror legislation as professor at the LSE and founding member of Matrix Chambers. In nearly 20 books—from Freedom Under Thatcher (1990) to Homeland Insecurity (2024)—and in columns, lectures and the 'Gearty Grillings' podcast, he argued that terrorism laws arbitrarily target protest, notably denouncing the UK ban on Palestine Action as politically motivated. A persuasive orator and mentor, he trained judges under the Human Rights Act, advised parliament and was appointed honorary QC in 2020. Renowned for wit and principle, he died suddenly aged 67.

articles.title: Brittany Higgins’ husband David Sharaz to pay $92,000 for tweet that defamed Linda Reynolds, court orders
articles.trailText: Sharaz also liable for former defence minister’s legal costs on an indemnity basis, which is expected to exceed $500,000
articles.summary: Western Australia’s Supreme Court has ordered David Sharaz to pay Linda Reynolds $92,000 in damages for defamatory tweets, and held him jointly liable with wife Brittany Higgins for a second tweet. Sharaz must also cover Reynolds’ indemnity costs, expected to top $500,000. The decision builds on an August ruling mandating Higgins pay $315,000 plus interest and 80% of legal fees (likely exceeding $1m), which she is appealing. Justice Tottle labeled the publications indefensible and said a settlement or apology should have preceded litigation.

articles.title: Baroness Hale on her stupendous, eye-opening life in the law: ‘People are capable of treating tiny children very, very badly’
articles.trailText: She was the first female president of the supreme court, causing a ruckus when she ruled against Boris Johnson’s suspension of parliament. Now she has written an insider’s take on the UK’s underfunded, overwhelmed justice system
articles.summary: Baroness Brenda Hale, first female president of the UK Supreme Court, became a household name after ruling Boris Johnson’s parliamentary prorogation unlawful in 2019. Now retired, she has published With the Law on Our Side, a three-part book introducing readers to courts, citizens’ rights and law-making, while unflinchingly criticising chronic underfunding of criminal and family justice. Hale profiles cases from benefits tribunals to rape sentencing and single-sex spaces, exposing systemic cruelty, political pressures on sentencing tariffs and the tireless dedication of legal staff. Impartial and candid, she blends legal insight with wry humour to demystify courts.
